form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Mr. Coats introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs

form.official-title: To amend title 5, United States Code, to establish uniform requirements for thorough economic analysis of regulations by Federal agencies based on sound principles, and for other purposes.

section.text:
This Act may be cited as the
Sound Regulation Act of 2014
.

paragraph.text: Growing Federal regulation that is highly prescriptive in nature burdens and impairs the international competitiveness of industry in the United States.
Prescriptive regulation takes away flexibility, is adversarial in nature, leads to unintended consequences, and, especially as it proliferates, slows economic growth and job creation.
Despite evidence of increasing regulatory costs, Federal agencies hold fast to the presumption that their rules are in the public interest.
Some statutes prohibit agencies from considering costs and benefits in rulemaking, although no statutes prohibit agencies from analyzing the costs and benefits of rules for informative purposes.

subparagraph.text: Cost-benefit analysis is not institutionalized for independent regulatory agencies.

Executive agencies perform cost-benefit analysis pursuant to Executive order and under the purview of the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs (commonly referred to as OIRA), which takes direction from the President.
Peer review is not required for cost-benefit analysis by independent regulatory agencies or executive agencies.
statutory standards for cost-benefit analysis in Federal rulemaking; or
consistent, material consequences when rules are based on faulty or inadequate analysis.
conduct their own regulatory impact analysis—

clause.text: largely by methods of their own choosing; and
only on a small fraction of the rules they issue; and

subparagraph.text: use regulatory cost-benefit analysis mainly in support of favored, preconceived rules rather than as a decision tool.

paragraph.text: Common deficiencies in the regulatory analysis used by agencies include—

subparagraph.text: lack of a coherent theory by which to—

clause.text: define a problem;
determine why the problem occurs; and
guide the agency to the most efficient response;

subparagraph.text: lack of objective evidence that an actionable problem actually exists, what its dimensions are, and how they differ from acceptable norms;
lack of comprehensive analysis to—

clause.text: determine whether a market malfunction exists; and
orient rulemaking to the causes, not the symptoms, of the market malfunction;

subparagraph.text: failure to set clear and realistic objectives whose benefits justify the cost of achieving the objectives;
objectives that—

clause.text: are disconnected from costs; and
may be expansive and vague so that any regulation can be made to appear beneficial;

subparagraph.text: agencies increasingly claiming—

clause.text: incidental benefits (also known as co-benefits) that are not in furtherance of the stated objective; and
even private, as opposed to public, benefits for rules;

subparagraph.text: failure to—

clause.text: develop regulatory options in light of market analysis; and
rank regulatory options by how efficiently they will improve the market process;

subparagraph.text: inconsistent assumptions and methodologies across agencies;
invalid baselines for gauging regulatory effects;
failure to reevaluate regulations after implementation; and
failure to consider the cumulative costs of regulation by the various Federal, State, local, and tribal agencies.
Despite continually changing market conditions, agencies do not—

clause.text: regularly review their existing regulations and regulatory regimes; or
review the division of functions—

subclause.text: among different Federal agencies; or
among Federal, State, local, and tribal agencies.

subparagraph.text: Regulations lose their purpose, yet linger and accumulate, imposing unnecessary costs and slowing economic growth to the detriment of—

clause.text: material living standards; and
to some extent, the very social conditions that are the objects of regulation.

subparagraph.text: Agencies typically do not—

clause.text: proactively conduct regulatory cost studies; and
report to Congress on unnecessary costs that are not under the control of the agencies because of the way laws are written.

subparagraph.text: Agency recommendations on how to improve the efficiency of regulation by modifying an existing statute could be helpful to Congress.

section.text: Section 553 of title 5, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following:

paragraph.text: Before an agency publishes or otherwise provides notice of a notice of proposed rulemaking under this section, the agency shall comply with the following requirements with respect to the proposed rule:

subparagraph.text: The agency shall identify, in the context of a coherent conceptual framework and supported with objective data—

clause.text: the nature and significance of the market failure, regulatory failure, or other problem that necessitates regulatory action;
the reasons why national economic and income growth, advancing technology, and other market developments will not obviate the need for the rulemaking;
the reasons why regulation at the State, local, or tribal level could not address the problem better than at the Federal level;
the reasons why reducing rather than increasing the extent or stringency of existing Federal regulation would not address the problem better; and
the particular authority under which the agency may take action.

subparagraph.text: Before the agency increases the extent or stringency of regulation based on its determinations pursuant to subparagraph (A), the agency shall—

clause.text: set an achievable objective for its regulatory action and identify the metrics by which the agency will measure progress toward the objective;
issue a notice of inquiry seeking public comment on the identification of a new objective under clause (i); and
give notice to the committees of Congress with jurisdiction over the subject matter of the rule.

subparagraph.text: If the agency is not seeking to repeal a rule, the agency shall develop not less than 3 distinct regulatory options, in addition to not regulating, that the agency estimates will provide the greatest benefits for the least cost in meeting the regulatory objective set under subparagraph (B) and, in developing such regulatory options, shall apply the following principles:

clause.text: The agency shall, to the extent practicable—

subclause.text: attempt to engage private incentives to solve a problem; and
not supplant private incentives any more than necessary.

clause.text: The agency shall consider the adverse effects that mandates and prohibitions may have on innovation, economic growth, and employment.

subclause.text: The agency’s risk assessment shall be confined to the jurisdiction of the agency, subject to specific regulatory authority.
Agency assessments of the risks of adverse health and environmental effects shall follow standardized parameters, assumptions, and methodologies.
The agency shall provide analyses of increases in risks, whatever their nature, produced by the regulatory options under consideration.

clause.text: The agency shall avoid incongruities and duplication in regulation at the Federal, State, local, and tribal levels.
The agency shall compare and contrast the regulatory options developed and explain how each would meet the regulatory objective set pursuant to subparagraph (B).

subparagraph.text: The agency shall estimate the costs and benefits of each regulatory option developed, notwithstanding any provision of law that prohibits the agency from using costs in rulemaking, at least to the extent that the agency is able to—

clause.text: exclude options whose costs exceed their benefits;
rank the options by cost from lowest to highest;

establish whether the cost of an option exceeds $50,000,000 for any 12-month period, except that the dollar amount shall be adjusted annually for inflation based on the GDP deflator, and the President may order that a lower dollar amount be used for a particular period;
identify the key uncertainties and assumptions that drive the results of the analysis under clause (iv); and
provide an analysis of how the ranking of the options and the threshold determination under clause (iv) may change if key assumptions are changed.

subparagraph.text: The estimates pursuant to subparagraph (D) shall—

clause.text: follow the methodology established pursuant to paragraph (2)(A);
to the maximum extent practicable, comply with any guidelines issued by the Administrator of the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs pertaining to cost-benefit analysis; and
include, at a minimum—

subclause.text: agency administrative costs;
United States private sector compliance costs;
Federal, State, local, and tribal compliance costs;
Federal, State, local, and tribal revenue impacts;
nationwide impacts on overall economic output, productivity, and consumer and producer prices;
international competitiveness of United States companies; and
distortions in incentives and markets, including an estimate of the resulting loss to the United States economy.

subparagraph.text: The agency shall—

clause.text: publish for public comment all analyses, documentation, and data under subparagraphs (A) through (D) for a public comment period of not less than 30 days (subject to applicable limitations under law, including laws protecting privacy, trade secrets, and intellectual property); and
correct deficiencies or omissions that the agency becomes aware of before choosing a rule to propose.
Beginning not later than the date that is 180 days after the date of enactment of the Sound Regulation Act of 2014 , each agency shall, by rule—

subclause.text: establish and maintain a specific cost-benefit analysis methodology appropriate to the functions and responsibilities of the agency; and

establish an appropriate period for review of new rules to assess the cost effectiveness of each such new rule at achieving the objective that the new rule was intended to address, as identified under paragraph (1)(B)(i).

clause.text: The methodology established by an agency under clause (i) shall—

subclause.text: include the standardized parameters, assumptions, and methodologies for agency assessments of risk under paragraph (1)(C)(iii);
not include consideration of incidental benefits but only those benefits that were considered in the establishment of the regulatory objective under paragraph (1);
limit consideration of costs and benefits to costs and benefits that accrue to the population of the United States;

constrain the agency from presuming that continued augmentation or tightening of mandates and additional prohibitions cause benefits and costs to change linearly but instead determine at what point benefits will rise less than, and costs will rise more than, proportionally;

include comparison of incremental benefits to incremental costs from any action the agency considers taking and refrain from actions whose incremental benefits do not exceed their incremental costs; and
include analysis of effects on private incentives and possible unintended consequences.

clause.text: Each agency shall adhere to the methodology established by the agency under this subparagraph in all rulemakings.

subparagraph.text: If an agency does not select the least-cost regulatory option as its proposed rule, the agency shall justify its selection, explaining—

clause.text: how that selection furthers other goals or requirements relevant to regulating matters within the jurisdiction of the agency and why these should override cost savings; and
why each of the other regulatory options not chosen would not sufficiently further such other goals or requirements.

subparagraph.text: Any person may petition an agency to amend an existing rule made prior to the establishment of methodology under this paragraph, and, if the agency denies such a petition, that denial shall be subject to review under chapter 7 of this title.

paragraph.text: If an agency makes a determination under paragraph (1)(D) that the monetized cost of a rule exceeds the applicable monetary limit under clause (iv) of such paragraph for any 12-month period—

subparagraph.text: the head of the agency shall—

clause.text: first issue an advanced notice of proposed rulemaking;
provide notice to the appropriate Congressional committees; and
keep the committees described in clause (ii) informed of the status of the rulemaking;

subparagraph.text: the agency shall—

clause.text: notify—

subclause.text: the Administrator of the Small Business Administration (referred to in this paragraph as the Administrator);
the Director of the Office of Management and Budget (referred to in this paragraph as the Director); and
affected parties; and

clause.text: provide each person described in clause (i) with information on—

subclause.text: the potential effects of the proposed rule on affected parties; and
the type of affected parties that might be affected;

subparagraph.text: not later than 15 days after the date of receipt of the information described in subparagraph (B)(ii), the Director, in consultation with the Administrator, shall—

clause.text: identify representatives of affected parties, not less than 25 percent of which shall, when possible, represent small business concerns (as such term is defined in section 3(a) of the Small Business Act ( 15 U.S.C. 623(a) )); and
provide each major stakeholder with the opportunity to obtain advice and recommendations about the potential effects of the proposed rule;

subparagraph.text: the agency shall convene a review panel that consists wholly of—

clause.text: full-time Federal officers, employees, and contractors in the agency;
the Director;
the Administrator; and
the representatives of affected parties identified under subparagraph (C)(i);

subparagraph.text: the agency shall—

clause.text: conduct a detailed analysis of the costs and benefits of the regulatory option that the agency is advancing; and
in conducting the detailed analysis under clause (i)—

subclause.text: identify the key uncertainties and assumptions that drive the results of the analysis; and

subparagraph.text: the review panel convened under subparagraph (D) shall review—

clause.text: all agency material prepared in connection with this subsection, including any draft proposed rule; and
the advice and recommendations of each representative of an affected party identified under subparagraph (C)(i);

subparagraph.text: not later than 60 days after the date on which the agency convenes the review panel under subparagraph (D)—

clause.text: the review panel shall report on—

subclause.text: the comments of each representative of an affected party identified under subparagraph (C)(i); and
the findings of the review panel as to issues related to the provisions of this subsection; and

clause.text: the report under clause (i) shall be made public as part of the rulemaking record;

subparagraph.text: if appropriate, the agency shall modify the proposed rule or the cost-benefit analysis under subparagraph (E) based on the report under subparagraph (G);
subject to applicable limitations under law, including laws protecting privacy, trade secrets, and intellectual property, the agency shall—

clause.text: publish for comment all analyses, documentation, and data under this subsection for a public comment period of not less than 30 days; and
correct deficiencies or omissions that the agency becomes aware of before adopting a proposed rule; and

subparagraph.text: the agency shall ensure that affected parties, including State, local, or tribal governments, and other stakeholders, may participate in the rulemaking, by means such as—

clause.text: the publication of advanced and general notices of proposed rulemaking in publications likely to be obtained by affected parties;
the direct notification of interested affected parties;
the conduct of open conferences or public hearings, including soliciting and receiving comments over computer networks; and
reducing the cost or complexity of procedural rules to ease participation in the rulemaking.

subparagraph.text: conduct a review of all rules of the agency that are in effect; and
determine based on objective data whether the rules are—

clause.text: working as intended;
furthering their objectives;
imposing unanticipated costs; or
generating a net benefit or not;

subparagraph.text: amend the rules if appropriate; and
report to Congress the findings of the review conducted under this paragraph.

paragraph.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, including any provision of law that explicitly prohibits the use of cost-benefit analysis in rulemaking, an agency shall conduct cost-benefit analyses and report to Congress the findings with specific recommendations for how to lower regulatory costs by amending the statutes prohibiting the use thereof.

subparagraph.text: the term regulatory options means any action an agency may take to address an objective identified under paragraph (1)(B)(i), including the option not to act;
the term private incentives—

clause.text: means financial gains or losses that motivate actions by private individuals and businesses; and
does not include any law or regulation that prescribes private actions or outcomes; and

subparagraph.text: the term incidental benefit means a claimed benefit outside the specific regulatory objective or objectives that a rule is intended to address, as identified under paragraph (1)(B)(i).

paragraph.text: All determinations made under this subsection shall be subject to review under chapter 7.

section.text: Section 801(a)(2) of title 5, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following:

subparagraph.text: The Comptroller General shall—

clause.text: examine any risk analysis under section 553(f)(1)(C)(iii) pertaining to the cost-benefit analysis for compliance with the requirements under section 553(f); and

subclause.text: examine the agencies’ quadrennial regulatory reviews conducted under section 553(f)(4) for consistency with the requirements under section 553(f); and
report to Congress on the results of the examination under subclause (I).
